title: The San Francisco Center for the Book
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20130922043851/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Education](http://web.archive.org/web/20130922043851/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Education) : The San Francisco Center for the Book**

Since it's opening in 1996, [The San Francisco Center for the Book](http://web.archive.org/web/20130922043851/http:/www.sfcb.org/index.php) is dedicated to providing educational resources in the book arts. The center offers workshops and exhibitions for varying degrees of expertise, welcoming just about anyone with an interest in books-arts or related crafts, from newcomers to experienced practitioners. Some of it's 300 [workshops](http://web.archive.org/web/20130922043851/http:/www.sfcb.org/php/classes.php) offered include year-long and introductory courses covering topics like traditional bookbinding methods and advanced printing techniques. In addition to the many workshops and [exhibitions](http://web.archive.org/web/20130922043851/http:/www.sfcb.org/html/exhibitions.html), the Center offers free events for the public and some that are designed specifically to reach out to Bay area communities, such as hands-on demonstrations for local schools and organizations.

The SFCB also serves as a venue for other book-arts organizations in the Bay Area, such as [The Pacific Center for the Book Arts](http://web.archive.org/web/20130922043851/http:/typophile.com/wiki/The%20Pacific%20Center%20for%20the%20Book%20Arts) and [The Hand Bookbinders of California.](http://web.archive.org/web/20130922043851/http:/typophile.com/wiki/The%20Hand%20Bookbinders%20of%20California.)

Past Exhibitions include:

• [Swiss Impressions: Romano Hänni and the Art of Metal Type](http://web.archive.org/web/20130922043851/http:/www.sfcb.org/html/past-hanni.html)  
• [Journey to the Source: Handmade Books from Cuba](http://web.archive.org/web/20130922043851/http:/www.sfcb.org/html/past-cuba.html)  
• [Massin in Continuo: A Dictionary](http://web.archive.org/web/20130922043851/http:/www.sfcb.org/html/past-massin.html)
author: Zara Evens
